Yes, there are current efforts to retrofit older buildings in areas prone to earthquakes and other natural disasters. In many earthquake-prone regions, governments have implemented mandatory retrofitting programs, which require building owners to ensure that their structures are seismically safe. For example, in California, there are mandatory retrofitting programs for unreinforced masonry buildings, which are the most vulnerable to earthquake damage. Similarly, in Japan, the government has implemented a program to retrofit older wooden structures to improve their seismic resistance.

These retrofitting programs typically provide financial incentives or assistance to building owners to cover the costs of retrofitting. Additionally, engineering firms and contractors specialize in retrofitting older buildings for improved seismic resistance, and there are ongoing research and development efforts to develop new retrofitting techniques and technologies.

The aim of these efforts is to decrease the risks and consequences of natural disasters on communities, safeguarding older buildings and infrastructure in areas prone to earthquakes, hurricanes, floods, and other types of natural disasters.
